CatDescriptText: Lois Roberts, housewife, 841 Francis Street and Edwin H. Beachler, radio-tv editorial writer, 286 Parkway Drive, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 5, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes should press in the fight for civil rights, or should they seek them through such medium as conciliation, persuasion and patience?" Lois Roberts' answer reads: "Not patience, because our patience has run out...It should be pressure."  Edwin H. Beachler's answer reads: "I think you have to press some, but there should be more effort through conciliation and working together...You don't want a conflict.  You can draw a parallel to the problems of labor and management and in this situation you cannot have the sides at each other's throat.  The same goes for the civil rights issue."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Lois Roberts wearing light colored tweed coat with dark buttons and collar, dark head scarf, and eyeglasses, holding cane, standing on sidewalk; Portrait of Edwin H. Beachler wearing dark flecked herringbone coat, fedora, and striped tie, standing on sidewalk
